title: Jack McCallister (baseball)
text:
John (Jack) McCallister (January 19, 1879 – October 18, 1946) was manager of the <a href="Cleveland%20Indians">Cleveland Indians</a> during the <a href="1927%20Cleveland%20Indians%20season">1927 season</a> after <a href="Tris%20Speaker">Tris Speaker</a> abruptly resigned. He would lead the Indians to a sixth-place finish and a 66-87 record.
He began his professional career in his native <a href="Marietta%2C%20Ohio">Marietta, Ohio</a>. In 1902, he was playing for the <a href="Hartford%20Senators">Hartford Senators</a> in the <a href="Connecticut%20League">Connecticut League</a>, and was expected to play for the <a href="St.%20Louis%20Cardinals">St. Louis Cardinals</a> of the <a href="National%20League">National League</a> the following year. However, in the fall of 1902 his knee was severely injured during a benefit game in Marietta, and he was unable to play for two years. After working as an umpire in 1905, he became a manager of the Portsmouth Cobblers of the <a href="Ohio%20State%20League">Ohio State League</a> in 1909; he later managed the Akron team in the <a href="Ohio%E2%80%93Pennsylvania%20League">Ohio–Pennsylvania</a> and <a href="Central%20League">Central</a> leagues. In 1913, the Indians hired him as a coach and scout. McCallister was Tris Speaker's primary assistant during his years as player-manager (1919–1926). McCallister became manager after Speaker's sudden resignation in late 1926. A second-place team in 1926, the Indians entered the <a href="1927%20Major%20League%20Baseball%20season">1927 season</a> with a largely unchanged roster, except that Hall of Fame center fielder Speaker now played in <a href="Washington%20Senators%20%281901%E2%80%9360%29">Washington</a>; the team won twenty-two fewer games in 1927. When asked about the reasons for the Indians' disappointing performance, McCallister replied, "I guess it is that I just can't play centerfield." Following a change of ownership at the end of the season, McCallister's contract was not renewed. After spending the 1928 season as a coach and scout for the <a href="1928%20Detroit%20Tigers%20season">Detroit Tigers</a>, he worked as a scout for the <a href="Boston%20Red%20Sox">Boston Red Sox</a> (1929–33), the <a href="1934%20Cincinnati%20Reds%20season">Cincinnati Reds</a> (1934), and the <a href="Boston%20Braves%20%28baseball%29">Boston Braves</a> (1936–46). He died in <a href="Columbus%2C%20Ohio">Columbus, Ohio</a>.
